The Spektr-RG mission has a primary goal of mapping the entire sky in X-rays with remarkable sensitivity and unprecedented detail. While its initial discoveries have already exceeded expectations, there are still many new discoveries that scientists hope to make with Spektr-RG.

One of the main goals of the Spektr-RG mission is to study the large-scale structure of the universe and understand how the structure of the universe forms and evolves over time. In particular, scientists hope to use the data to study dark energy, which is believed to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe.

Another area of study is black holes and their activity, with the aim of understanding the mechanisms that power and regulate their growth. Spektr-RG is also expected to detect thousands of new galaxy clusters, helping to better understand the formation and evolution of these massive structures.

Furthermore, scientists hope to use the data from Spektr-RG to better understand the processes that lead to the formation and evolution of stars and galaxies, as well as to study the physical properties of various astrophysical objects and phenomena, including supernovae and cosmic rays.

Overall, Spektr-RG has the potential to unveil some of the most profound mysteries of the universe and significantly advance our understanding of the cosmos.
